author: chris2_2_2
content: I saw Ethermine and others proposing to increase gas limits on blocks. Is this feasible? I recall during the 1559 discussion that it was stated that the current limit as high as it could go without overly burdening existing hardware/software.

author: bridge-bot
content: <vbuterin> Gas limit seems to be equilibrating around 13m at the moment

author: bridge-bot
content: <vbuterin> I am guessing that some mining pool was already targeting 13m all along, and a different pool raised the target to 15m and now the limit is stuck at 13m because if it goes higher that 13m pool's hashrate is enough to make it go back downward

author: alexssd7fp
content: Oh come on! I don't think that it is a good idea. This will harm the decentralization of the Ethereum network. Running a full node is already expensive AF.

author: timbeiko
content: The reason why it is less of an issue now is that EIP-2929, which went live in Berlin, mitigates some DoS risks of having the high gas limit. On the other hand, the long term effects of larger blocks are still not mitigated.

author: chris2_2_2
content: There's going to be a lot of discussion and fud over this now that its being discussed on miner channels...and likely will move on to eth general channels.

author: alexssd7fp
content: The problem is that it didn't fix the issue. It just made the fee more expensive, aka the same transaction costs more in gas. I'm not sure what % of total operations is state access, but I think that it is at least majority.

author: alexssd7fp
content: If it is the vast majority, then increasing it to 15,000,000 will be close to just reverting that EIP

author: bridge-bot
content: <vbuterin> Daily transactions hit an ATH post-Berlin, and the pre-Berlin analysis showed increased almost completely offset by decreases on average, so I doubt that EIP 2929 made things much more expensive across the board

author: bridge-bot
content: <vbuterin> though I'm sure some specific apps were unlucky
